Treadmill question -

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎04-08-2014 12:34 PM

Hello All

 

I have been researching about treadmills.  I found one I like but it's only a 1.5 HP.  It's at Wal-Mart and I like it because it is a stand to hold my computer etc.  You can actually use it like a desk.  So I can prop my Kindle, or listen to music or surf the web and walk away throughtly entertained.  (It won't fit in living room, too many people and furniture so I have to provide my own entertainment while exercising or I will get bored instantly).

 

Does anyone have any comments about a lower HP or am I better off with a 2.0 or 2.5 HP.  I've been looking at treadmills in the $500 to $700.

 

Thank you

Alli7 aka Allison in Northeast Ohio
Both parents diabetic -bummer and not surprised at diagnosis
A1c 6.6% in Nov 2012 Current A1c is 5.6%!!
Starting weight: 226 Current weight: 203 7/3/13
2014 last known A1c 6.0% current weight on home scale -216

‎04-08-2014 04:02 PM

I don't know about what the 1.5 vs 2.5 HP diffeence in performance would be.  But I do think you have a very good idea about the shelf for kindle or computer.

 

I use a treadmill for at least an hour, at the gym, almost every day and Ipod for music and kindle for reading make the time fly.  I has gotten me through the cold and snowy winter.

‎04-08-2014 07:03 PM

Alli7 wrote:

Hello All

 

I have been researching about treadmills.  I found one I like but it's only a 1.5 HP.  It's at Wal-Mart and I like it because it is a stand to hold my computer etc.  You can actually use it like a desk.  So I can prop my Kindle, or listen to music or surf the web and walk away throughtly entertained.  (It won't fit in living room, too many people and furniture so I have to provide my own entertainment while exercising or I will get bored instantly).

 

Does anyone have any comments about a lower HP or am I better off with a 2.0 or 2.5 HP.  I've been looking at treadmills in the $500 to $700.

 

Thank you

If you have the model number, you should be able to look up the specs and max weight recommendations online.  (And WalMart should also have the owner's manual or be able to print it out for you.)  For walking, a 1.5 HP treadmill should do the job, but for running, the recommendations are usually for higher HP.  You might also want to take into consideration who else might be using it.  Have you tried it out, and how well does it work?

Nancy ~ T2 since '98 ~ 17 yrs ~ D&E 11yrs ~ treadmill, elliptical, bike 15-20 minutes 2-3x/day (includes evenings), dumbbells/strength-training, small portions heart-healthy high-fiber/low-fat fuel/carb-counting, modified Mediterranean/semi-vegetarian plant-based diet; 500mg Glucophage XR x4, 5mg Glipizide ER x4, 4000IU Vit. D/day ~ RHR 55 ~ Between 5.9-6.9 A1cs, av. 6.5

‎04-08-2014 09:12 PM

Unfortunately, I haven't been able to try out the Wal-Mart ones. They don't have any in the stores near me.  So, I'm just going of the online info.  I did get to try some at the Dick's sporting goods store and they were about the same price but no way to "shelf" anything.

 

I guess I'll keep looking and getting info, but I really do like the shelf idea.  The others that I have seen do this are over $1,000 bucks but they do have a bigger motor. 

 

Right now I just want to get walking and build my stamina.

 

Thanks for the help!

Alli7 aka Allison in Northeast Ohio
Both parents diabetic -bummer and not surprised at diagnosis
